declarations.comments: Projects a value from the global context in a `MonadAsk`.
declarations.title: asks

declarations.comments: Set the state.
declarations.title: put

declarations.comments:
Modify the state by applying a function to the current state. The returned
value is the new state value.
declarations.title: modify

declarations.comments: Get a value which depends on the current state.
declarations.title: gets

declarations.comments: Get the current state.
declarations.title: get

declarations.comments:
Shorthand for constructing n-tuples as nested pairs.
`a /\ b /\ c /\ d /\ unit` becomes `Tuple a (Tuple b (Tuple c (Tuple d unit)))`

Shorthand for constructing n-tuple types as nested pairs.
`forall a b c d. a /\ b /\ c /\ d /\ Unit` becomes
`forall a b c d. Tuple a (Tuple b (Tuple c (Tuple d Unit)))`
declarations.title: type (/\)

declarations.comments:
Represents rendered React VDOM (the result of calling `React.createElement`
in JavaScript).

`JSX` is a `Monoid`:

- `append`
  - Merge two `JSX` nodes using `React.Fragment`.
- `mempty`
  - The `empty` node; renders nothing.

__*Hint:* Many useful utility functions already exist for Monoids. For example,
  `guard` can be used to conditionally render a subtree of components.__
declarations.title: JSX

declarations.comments:
Run renderless Halo in the current component. This allows Halo to be used with other hooks and other ways of
building components.
declarations.title: useHalo

declarations.comments: Build a propless component by providing a name and Halo component spec.
declarations.title: component_

declarations.comments: Build a component by providing a name and Halo component spec.
declarations.title: component

declarations.comments:
The Halo evaluation monad. It lifts the `HaloF` algebra into a free monad.

- `props` are the component props
- `state` is the component state
- `action` is the set of actions that the component handles
- `m` is the monad used during evaluation
- `a` is the result type
declarations.title: HaloM

declarations.comments:
The Halo parallel evaluation applicative. It lifts `HaloM` into a free applicative.

- `props` are the component props
- `state` is the component state
- `action` is the set of actions that the component handles
- `m` is the monad used during evaluation
- `a` is the result type
declarations.title: HaloAp

declarations.comments: Cancels the event subscription belonging to the `SubscriptionId`.
declarations.title: unsubscribe

declarations.comments:
Same as `subscribe` but the event-producing logic is also passed the `SuscriptionId`. This is useful when events
need to unsubscribe themselves.
declarations.title: subscribe'

declarations.comments:
Subscribe to new actions from an `Event`. Subscriptions will be automatically cancelled when the component
unmounts.

Returns a `SubscriptionId` which can be used with `unsubscribe` to manually cancel a subscription.
declarations.title: subscribe

declarations.comments: Read the current props.
declarations.title: props

declarations.comments: Kills the process belonging to the `ForkId`.
declarations.title: kill

declarations.comments: Hoist (transform) the base monad of a `HaloM` expression.
declarations.title: hoist

declarations.comments:
Start a `HaloM` process running independantly from the current "thread". Forks are tracked automatically and
killed when the `Finalize` event occurs (when the component unmounts). New forks can still be created during the
`Finalize` event, but once evaluation ends there will be no way of killing them.

Returns a `ForkId` for the new process.
declarations.title: fork

declarations.comments:
A simpler interface for building the components eval function. The main lifecycle events map directly into
actions, so only the action handling logic needs to be written using `HaloM`.
declarations.title: EvalSpec

declarations.comments: Given an `EvalSpec` builder, it will return an eval function.
declarations.title: makeEval

declarations.comments: The empty `EvalSpec`.
declarations.title: defaultEval

declarations.comments:
The Halo lifecycle events.

- `Initialize` contains the initial props. It occurs when the component mounts, and only once per component.
- `Update` contains the previous and new props. It occurs when the component re-renders and the props have changes.
- `Action` contains the dispatched action. It occurs each time an action is dispatched to be eval'd, up until the
  `Finalize` event
- `Finalize` occurs when the component unmounts.
declarations.title: Lifecycle

building components.

declarations.comments: Hoist (transform) the base applicative of a `HaloAp` expression.
declarations.title: hoistAp

declarations.comments: Read the current props.
declarations.title: props

declarations.comments:
Subscribe to new actions from an `Event`. Subscriptions will be automatically cancelled when the component
unmounts.

Returns a `SubscriptionId` which can be used with `unsubscribe` to manually cancel a subscription.
declarations.title: subscribe

declarations.comments:
Same as `subscribe` but the event-producing logic is also passed the `SuscriptionId`. This is useful when events
need to unsubscribe themselves.
declarations.title: subscribe'

declarations.comments: Cancels the event subscription belonging to the `SubscriptionId`.
declarations.title: unsubscribe

declarations.comments:
Start a `HaloM` process running independantly from the current "thread". Forks are tracked automatically and
killed when the `Finalize` event occurs (when the component unmounts). New forks can still be created during the
`Finalize` event, but once evaluation ends there will be no way of killing them.

Returns a `ForkId` for the new process.
declarations.title: fork

declarations.comments: Kills the process belonging to the `ForkId`.
declarations.title: kill

declarations.comments: Interprets `HaloM` into the base monad `Aff` for asynchronous effects.
declarations.title: evalHaloM

declarations.comments: Interprets `HaloAp` into the base applicative `ParAff` for parallel effects.
declarations.title: evalHaloAp

declarations.comments: Interprets `HaloF` into the base monad `Aff`, keeping track of state in `HaloState`.
declarations.title: evalHaloF

declarations.comments:
A simpler interface for building the components eval function. The main lifecycle events map directly into
actions, so only the action handling logic needs to be written using `HaloM`.
declarations.title: EvalSpec

declarations.comments: The empty `EvalSpec`.
declarations.title: defaultEval

declarations.comments: Given an `EvalSpec` builder, it will return an eval function.
declarations.title: makeEval

declarations.comments: Simple way to run Aff logic asynchronously, while bringing errors back into Effect.
declarations.title: runAff

declarations.comments: HThe alo component state used during evaluation.
declarations.title: HaloState

declarations.comments: Creates a starting `HaloState`, ready for initialization.
declarations.title: createInitialState

declarations.comments: Issue a new identifier, unique to this component.
declarations.title: fresh

declarations.comments:
The Halo lifecycle events.

- `Initialize` contains the initial props. It occurs when the component mounts, and only once per component.
- `Update` contains the previous and new props. It occurs when the component re-renders and the props have changes.
- `Action` contains the dispatched action. It occurs each time an action is dispatched to be eval'd, up until the
  `Finalize` event
- `Finalize` occurs when the component unmounts.
declarations.title: Lifecycle
